titleStmt.title: Despatch from M. A. Aenmey to William Hunter, March 29, 1882

bibl.title: Despatch from M. A. Aenmey to William Hunter
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: Second Assistant U.S. Secretary of State

div1.p:
United States Consulate General
at Monrovia, Liberia
March 29th 1882
M. A Aenmey to the Second Asst Secy of State
Arrival of the U.S. Naval ship Essex
Arrival of the ship. Official visit of Commander McCormick on shore. Entertainement at the executive mansion, in honor of the arrival of the ship. depart of the ship from Monrovia.

Consulate of the United States
Monrovia, March 29, 1882
M. A Aenmey to the Second Assistt Secretary of State

Sir– I have the honor to respectfully inform the Department, that, the U.S. naval ship Essex arrived at the port of Monrovia, on the morning of the 24th of March; at 10 o'clock a.m. a boat arrived on shore and the officer tendered me a passage to the ship; where I had an interview with Commander McCormick.

The next day, Commander McCormick was officially recived by the President of the Republic of Liberia In presence of the Secretaries of State and Interior. I accompanied the Commander to the Executive Mansion, and presented him to the President and aforesaid Gentlemen.

After exchange of the ordinary civilitico, Commander McCormick informed the President of his instructions in connection with his probable stay on this coast, and also that the ship was short in coals and provisions; for which reasons, he would like to sail a soon as practicable for Montevideo

On Monday March 27th in honor of the arrival of the U.S. naval ship Essex, the President of Liberia gave
gave an official entertainement to Commander McCormick and other officers of the Essex to which, the members of the Consular Corps and principal government officials were invited.

There were present, Commander McCormick and officers of the Essex, the Consular officers of the Netherlands, Sweden & Norway, Haïty and the U.S. of America, the members of Cabinet, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, the Colonel and other officers of the first Regiment and several other officials and distinguished guests.

Sentiments of Friendships and toasts were given as usual at official gatherings; the first toast was proposed by the President of Liberia for the healt and prosperity of the President of the U.S. of America.

The same afthernoon Commander McCormick was officially informed that 1e the presence of Governor Havelock with two English man of wars in harbor to present their claim upon before the Liberian Government. 2e the daily proceedings of the Commissioners appointed to discuss aforesaid claim, occupied all his time and attention; and there not being any natif revolts at the present time, the President requests the Commander, to take on board two Gentelman
telmen, sent by the Government of Liberia to Grand Bassa, Sinou and Cape Palmas, to summon the Senators from aforesaid County's for an extra session of the Senate to consider the claim of H.B.M. Government.

Wednesday the 29 of March the two Gentelmen appointed by the Government went on board and at 5 o'clock pm the Essex weighed anchor and proceeded to Grand Bassa, Sinou and Cape Palmas from which port the Commander will sail on or about the 31st of March for Montevideo.
The healt of all on board is reported in good condition

With high consideration of esteem
I am Sir your obedt servt
M. A Aenmey
U.S. Vice Consul Genl
